text: a first glimpse of the ancient city of
Palmyra after it was retaken from the so
called Islamic state this footage has
come as a relief to many it shows a lot
of the 2000 year old Roman ruins still
standing columns and colonnades even the
amphitheater appears to have survived
the militant groups occupation of the
city but we know they blew up at least
two historic temples the rest of the
damage is yet to be assessed and look at
the crude fortifications they built in
and around the ruins like this bunker
for example it has taken days of intense
fighting by the Syrian army backed by
Russian airstrikes to retake the city
military sources say they now have full
control but as the militants retreated a
series of apparent car bombs were set
off on the outskirts of the city the
Syrian President Bashar al-assad said
the recapture was an important
achievement in the war on terrorism
symbolically and strategically it is as
much a victory for the government as it
is a defeat for is the Syrian
Observatory for Human Rights estimates
around 400 is fighters were killed in
the battle the monitoring organization
says it's the group's single biggest
defeat for two years but the modern
district which they also occupied is now
something of a ghost city streets
deserted buildings damaged and artifacts
at the museum destroyed the militants
reportedly took civilians with them to
other territories still under their
control
the Syrian army said it will use the
city it's recaptured as a launch pad to
expand operations against is and cut its
vital supply routes been planned BBC
news
